newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call eases, seen range-bound this fortnight.
newsitem.headline: Indian call eases, seen range-bound this fortnight.

text.p: Indian call money rates opened steady at 5.25-5.75 percent and eased to 4.25-4.75 percent in late morning trade on Monday, dealers said.
The call rates are expected to be in the 5.0-7.0 percent range in the new fortnight despite large outflows on account repo auction and advance tax payment, they said.
At the June 19 repo auction, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised 45.5 billion rupees, a sharp jump from 11.0 billion rupees raised at the June 16 auction.
State-run banks are actively lending in the call market as they are flush with funds and credit offtake has been poor.
An official at the state-run Bank of Baroda said tax outflows have not left the banking system.
"Banks can collect upto June 30," he said.
RBI's dollar purchases from the inter-bank foreign exchange market has also been adding to domestic liquidity, dealers said.
RBI was active throughout last week, buying dollars at 35.82 level, to arrest the rupee's rise against the U.S. currency.
Security prices were quoted higher in early Monday, dealers said.
The RBI is conducting an auction of four day repos on Monday evening.
